When a small group of living beings (a small population) is separated from the main population from which it originated (for example, if it moves above a mountain range or a river, or if it moves to a new island so that it cannot easily return), it often finds itself in a different environment from the one in which it was previously.

This new environment has different resources and competitors, so that the new population will need new characteristics or adaptations in order to be a strong competitor compared to what it needed before.
The population of origin has not changed at all, it still needs the same adaptations.
Over time, as the new population adapts to its new environment, it begins to resemble less and less the other population.
Finally, after thousands or even millions of years, the two populations will appear so different that they will no longer be considered to belong to the same species.
We call this process "speciation", which simply means the formation of new species. Speciation is an inevitable consequence and an important part of evolution.

Technological determinism is a term that encompasses a wide range of ideas in practice, ranging from technological push or technological imperative to a strict sense in which the destiny of humanity is dictated by an underlying logic linked to scientific laws and their manifestation in technologies.

Most interpretations of technological determinism agree on two general ideas: the development of technology itself takes place beyond the influence of cultural and political factors, and technology has an impact on societies that is intrinsic rather than social.
For example, one could say that the automobile necessarily leads to the development of roads.
However, a national road network is not economically viable for a handful of cars, which is why new production methods are being developed to reduce the cost of owning a car.
The massive possession of cars also leads to a greater incidence of accidents on the roads, which leads to the invention of new techniques in the field of health care to treat the physical injuries.

In the savanna, it is difficult for a primate with a digestive system similar to that of humans to satisfy its needs in amino acids from the available vegetable resources.

The most easily accessible plant resources would be the proteins contained in leaves and legumes, but they are difficult to digest for primates like us, unless they are cooked.
In contrast, the food of animal origin (ants, termites, eggs) is easy to digest while providing a large quantity of proteins containing all the essential amino acids.
All things considered, we should not be surprised if our own ancestors resolved their "protein problem" in much the same way as the chimpanzees of the savannah do today.

After its adoption by the Congress on July 4, a handwritten manuscript signed by the President of the Congress John Hancock and the Secretary Charles Thomson was then sent to a few streets away, at the printing house of John Dunlap.
During the night, between 150 and 200 copies were made, today known as the "Dunlap Broadsides".
The first public reading of the document was made by John Nixon in the Independence Hall courtyard on July 8.
One of them was sent to George Washington on 6 July, who had it read to his troops in New York on 9 July. A copy arrived in London on 10 August.
The 25 Dunlap broadsides of which we still know the existence are the oldest copies of the document. The original manuscript has not survived.

Traffic flow is the study of the movements of drivers and individual vehicles between two points, and the interactions they have with each other.

Fortunately, drivers tend to act in a reasonable range of coherence; thus, traffic flows tend to have a reasonable coherence and can be represented mathematically in an approximate manner.
To better represent the traffic flow, relationships have been established between the three main characteristics: (1) the flow rate, (2) the density and (3) the speed.

The modern city of Casablanca was founded by Berber fishermen in the 10th century BC, and was used by the Phoenicians, the Romans and the Merinides as a strategic port called Anfa.
The Portuguese, who had destroyed it and then rebuilt it and baptized it Casa Branca, finally abandoned it in 1755 after an earthquake.
The Moroccan sultan rebuilt the city under the name of Daru l-Badya, and it was renamed Casablanca by the Spanish merchants who established trading posts there.

The Sundarbans have been declared a World Heritage Site by UNESCO. The part of the forest located on the Indian territory is called Sundarbans National Park.
The forests are not, however, composed solely of mangrove swamps: they also contain some of the last remnants of the majestic jungles that once covered the plains of the Ganges.
The Sundarbans cover an area of 3,850 km2, of which about a third is covered by water/marshes.

The stirrups are supports for the feet of the rider, which hang on either side of the saddle.
